thread.title: Boys' Soccer: Wayne rivals advance in PCT
thread.title_full: Boys' Soccer: Wayne rivals advance in PCT

title: Boys' Soccer: Wayne rivals advance in PCT
text:
Print 
WAYNE - There's no denying that Wayne Valley has taken the long way to the Passaic County Coaches' Association boys' soccer tournament semifinals. 
When the Indians received the No. 9 seed, they were forced to play two preliminary round matches before reaching the quarterfinals, where a well rested top-seed Passaic Valley was awaiting. 
Funny thing, though, since last month's seeding meeting, Wayne Valley is not playing like a low seed and back in the semifinals for the first time since 2011. 
The Indians (5-7) will face a familiar opponent when they play fifth-seeded Clifton Saturday at 4 o'clock in Clifton School Stadium. 
"Clifton moves the ball well," Wayne Valley boss Sam Roca said. 
Roca and the Indians learned that first-hand on Oct. 8 in a 2-1 double-overtime setback to Clifton. This week's semifinal will be played on a large FIFA-sized smooth pitch. The stadium's recent renovation project included FieldTurf, which favors possession-oriented teams, but is quite slick when wet. 
Clifton can push the pace or form a defensive barrier. Seniors Frankie Salensky, Bruno Frascolla and Romario DePalmar are the leaders and sophomores Tommy Miazga and Michael Algieri are the future of the program. 
Wayne Valley's back four of Aneesh Bhave, Matt Bleeker, Scott Sherin and Brandon Vecere have bonded, while senior goalkeeper Matt Mihalik has been solid. 
"I'm happy for the players; they've bonded," Roca added. 
2-Hawthorne Christian vs. 6-Wayne Hills, 2 p.m.: The opening game in Clifton has teeth. The Patriots' stingy defense must contend with Rene White and Will Woodfin. White is a prolific scorer, but set up two goals in the Defenders 3-1 win over Passaic in the quarterfinals. Last year, Wayne Hills toppled HCA, 5-4, in a wild quarterfinal. The Patriots seem to be mounting another late season push, using the counties as a springboard. That means coach Nelson Graham's side is within touching distance of a seventh crown. HCA is looking to reach the program's first final. 
Editor's note: Fans should arrive early to Clifton School Stadium -located on Route 46 West behind Christopher Columbus Middle School-because parking in the adjacent school lot is limited. 
Patriots, Indians in girls' semis 
Whereas the boys' tournament has a few wrinkles in its bracket, the girls' top four seeds advanced to the semifinals. 
The girls' tournament will play its semifinals Saturday at Wayne Valley's stadium: 
1-Wayne Hills vs. 4-Wayne Valley, 4 p.m.: The second game of the doubleheader is a Wayne derby. How fortuitous! Wayne Valley showed resilience last week, scoring twice after the interval to turn back fifth-seeded DePaul Catholic, 3-2. Randi Smith (13 goals), Alexa Simonetti and Imani Thompson are Wayne Valley's primary scoring threats, while Jen Cannarella is the playmaker. 
Wayne Hills bounced back in the quarterfinals after a rare regular-season loss (4-0 to IHA) and have already beaten Wayne Valley, 2-1, on Sept. 21. (They play again on Oct. 27 in league play.) 
The Patriots defend well and feature Meghan Griffin, who drives the offensive engine. Both programs have won 11 county titles, with the winner gaining the inside track for a dozen. Needless to say, the stakes are high. 
2-Clifton vs. 3-Lakeland, 2 p.m.: The Mustangs opened the week unbeaten in 11 games and continue their march to the county final. The semifinals won't be easy on a neutral field. 
Clifton's backline with Chelsea Robinson and Sharon Garcia are in synch, while the midfield has playmaker Brittany Morales and up front there's Daniella LoBue and high-scoring Meaghan Mancini (12 goals). 
The Lancers were scoreless at the break last weekend, but rallied for a 4-0 win over Hawthorne.
